Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned the basic groundwork of the field of linguistics  including phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, and semantics. It was a lot more scientific than I was expecting, and I had to become good at picking out patterns from a data set. It teaches you a new way to think about language, for sure.
I gained an incredible understanding of language and the myriad ways in which it affects our lives and perceptions, as well as an understanding of phonetics, phonology, morphology, and syntax.

I applied to Yale as a linguistics major, and this course really helped clarify what linguistics actually was. I really liked how this course broadened my sense of awareness towards language, especially with microvariations in language. Overall, it was well taught, at times challenging, but I learned a lot.

Students learn the basics of key fields of linguistics: phonetics, phonology, morphology, and syntax.  Students explore the intricacies of English and other languages (with data sets and translations).  Students not only employ prescriptive rules of grammar, but explore situations where those rules are not followed.
Understanding of the structure, creation, and evolution of language over time, and how socioeconomic factors play into our understanding and perception of language.

This was my first foray into the linguistics world and because everything was brand knew, I think I learned the most I have ever learned in a Yale course before... language acquisition, biases in language/dialect perceptions, phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, ASL, microvariaton, etc!

We learned a lot of technical skills for analyzing different aspects of language the way that linguists would. I learned a lot from this course but often times the material was too technical to be interesting.

I learned basic information about phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, and the field of linguistics as a whole. I also learned how to approach problems in a certain way and how to think about language from the perspective of linguistics.
This was an excellent introductory course.

Skills in introductory level linguistic analysis in phonetics, phonology, morphology, and syntax in addition to skills in sharing those concepts with people not familiar with them in simple and engaging ways

I gained a significant general understanding of the way languages function, as well as a profound appreciation for language itself. I now can recognize and appreciate various linguistic phenomena in my everyday life.

I gained a better understanding of word formation, sentence structure, how word sounds are perceived based on context, and ways to think about how our brains process grammar. I was really interested in word sounds in Shakespeare and the intricacies of language in general, and it was interesting to break down the different components of language formally.
A survey of phonetics, phonology, morphology and syntax.

I learned how to read IPA, we covered a variety of topics from phonetics to phonology to morphology and finally syntax. I learned a lot about the reason behind why languages follow certain grammatical rules and pronunciations. I learned how languages across the world are very similar but also have many differences.

I learned the basics of linguistics topics phonetics, phonology, morphology, and some syntax. I also learned how to analyze data sets to come to a conclusion and talk about it. I also learned a couple of other random topics like the linguistics of sign language, microvariation.
From this course I gained a strong "high-level" view of linguistics and several of its sub-fields (phonetics, phonology, morphology, and syntax).
Introduction to the field of Linguistics, good understanding of linguistic concepts and of where in the field my interests lie.
I learned a lot about linguistics and the intricacies of language. This is information that I found fascinating even if it didn't come naturally to me.
Gained an overview of the study of linguistics. Definitely gained a greater awe for language. Also learned to think in a different way - hypothesis testing in a whole new realm.

This is an absolutely fantastic course! I came to Yale wanting to be a linguistic major and Ling 110 absolutely affirmed my plans. 

The class can be conceptually tricky for some as it requires you to throw out the window almost every single thing you thought you knew - or didn't even know you thought you knew - about language, but I personally found this exhilarating and was able to learn SO much.

The workload is totally manageable and the lectures really help you understand that material. The quizzes are reasonable - if you study, go to every lecture, and meet with Jim/the TAs if you are confused, you will be fine. There is also ample opportunity for participation in both lecture and section.

The only little improvement would be that we do not really get a lot of feedback on our problem sets, but I think the grading - on quizzes especially - was quite reasonable.

I wish for practice problems that an answer key could be posted each time instead of emailing professors for each question. However, professors were very quick to respond to any questions whether it was through Piazza, email, or office hours.

Strengths:
strong, interesting, and engaging lecture
students gain thorough understanding of all topics covered
problem sets supplement lecture learning very well

Jim Wood is a great lecturer, and the problem sets directly relate to the material we cover. The class is very easy and doesn't take up that much time at all, which is a bonus. A bit boring at times but all-in-all a great class to take as your 5th or 6th credit.

I think this course is very well organized. The weekly problem sets and three quizzes ensure that students are reviewing/mastering material, and section provides a great opportunity for review and practice.

The main strength is Professor Wood as a lecturer and a person. He knows how to make the lectures engaging and interesting and he's very accessible to all the students if we have questions or just want to talk about linguistics.
There were, however, a couple of weaknesses that really got in the way of enjoying this class a lot of the time. Sections were pointless and not very helpful, and my TF wasn't prepared to answer most of the questions. And there were more than a couple of classes that Professor Wood wasn't there for, which was fine, but the substitute lectures from the TF felt like he was just looking at the powerpoints for the first time and hadn't reviewed the material since undergrad. 
As for homework, the readings were really good and enhanced my understanding of the material, but the problem sets were always more annoying and tedious than helpful practice. They often consisted of long, convoluted problems that could be solved easily if they could be done handwritten, but instead we had to type in weird and annoying formats, as well as needlessly retype all the excessively long questions into our answers. For multiple homeworks, the questions were so confusing that Professor Wood had to make an entire FAQ page just to complete one assignment.
The last weak point for me was how arbitrarily the assignments and quizzes were graded. For some reason, all the homeworks were out of 5 points, so if you did a great job but had a couple small mistakes that would normally warrant an A-, you would probably end up with a 4/5 which is an 80%. And lastly, grades were often very late to come back to us which left us with very little feedback on how to improve.
Also, 10% of the final grade is based on participation, which is a little strange for a good-sized lecture like this one.

The course was well taught and formatted well. However, feedback on homeworks and quizzes was always quite behind, so I never really felt prepared for the next assignment or quiz. In addition, the instructors rarely posted answer keys and were not very helpful in general with feedback. Grading of the overall course was not very transparent.
The lectures were clear and concise. The course would benefit if only Jim Wood taught it.

Well-designed course with interesting lectures and problem sets that felt relevant to material covered in class and assessed on quizzes. Clarity, consistency, and transparency of homework grading could be improved. Often homework would show only a few comments with more points taken off than the comments seemed to reflect. Homework grades often felt inconsistent with level of understanding and performance on quizzes. This problem was partially fixed with the curving of the homework grades to 4.6 instead of 5 but could still be improved to better reflect performance in the class and level of understanding of the content.

Jim Wood is a great lecturer! At times, especially in the later portions of the course, I felt that he went a little too fast to take notes effectively, but the lecture slides posted were more than enough to study from. I also found it hard to get full credit on the psets for the first few weeks of the course. If you know LaTeX, that may help boost your grade. But overall, the course was enjoyable and that was all i was hoping for. NOT a gut class if you dont have the best QR skills - dont be fooled.
This course was very well organized, in terms of structure and having all of the materials available online. One weakness was that it often took a long time for grades to get back to us.
It provides a good introduction to each topic, and the transition between topics is seamless. Lessons and sections were structured well and exams were fair.

Strengths: interesting topic, very organized class and structure, Professor Wood makes the class fun and engaging, there is one pset a week which is pretty nice in my opinion, the TA's are always willing to help as well as Professor Wood

Weaknesses: The psets are due every Tuesday which was not the best because we sometimes learned everything we needed to know to do the pset right before it is due, the homeworks did not always directly translate to what we did in class, there is a required section to this class that meets every week
This class was unorganized. We were not assigned sections until late in the semester, and our homework was returned very late (the last homework was returned a couple of weeks after the final exam).

Strengths are the topics and teachers, they were all excellent. The topics covered were interesting and well-reviewed by the homeworks and exams. I really liked the 3  quiz format and I enjoyed section. One small weakness was that I got a bit lost at the end with the merge/move/agree syntax stuff.

Professor Wood is a great professor who puts a lot of effort into making his lectures interesting.  The problem-sets for this course were (for the most part) manageable and contributed to my understanding of the course content.

Overall a very good survey course. I would have preferred less of a focus on phonetics and phonology, but I know other students felt differently, and I think it's a matter of preference. Sections were good and helpful, grading was fair.

It is a good amount of material, but if it doesn't come naturally to you then you don't always get the underlying conceptual stuff until towards the end of the class. The homeworks made it difficult to do well but this was changed when the grade distribution was seen to be quite low. The instructor Prof. Wood is very good and does make the class fun.

Strengths: engaging lectures, helpful assignments, great teachers
Improvements: more encouragement/availability to seek help with assignments

Not a gut, but the class gets easier as the semester passes. As an English major also studying foreign languages, this was very insightful and helpful. If you have an open mind and want to learn about a realm of study that you probably haven't ever thought about, take this!

If you are interested in linguistics, yes, for sure. linguistics is an important field that most of us dont get exposure to in high school so it is nice to learn something about it now even if you dont go on to major in it.

Yes!!! Every single person should be required to take this course. Most people live their entire lives with SO many incorrect linguistic notions that lead us to make damaging, misguided judgements of others - taking this class will forever change your perception of language. Beyond this, the phonetics, phonology, morphology, and syntax units are very well taught and absolutely fascinating.
I would recommend this course to a student, and sometimes I think IPA should be learned by everyone to facilitate language learning.
If you've ever had an interest in language, how it comes to be, and how we acquire it, you should definitely take this course! You'll learn a lot through interesting lectures and problem sets.
If you need a 5th or 6th credit, this is it!
Yes. If you're interested in linguistics, it's well worth it. It's an excellent overview, and, despite being a lecture course, is quite interactive.
Yes, there is definitely a learning curve in the morphology unit, but then it just becomes more and more interesting! Makes you think about something we do everyday in a whole new way!

This course is for people that don't know if they'd be interested in linguistics and want a broad introduction to the four main areas of the field (phonetics, phonology, morphology, and syntax). If you're interested in other areas of linguistics (semantics, pragmatics, psycholinguistics, sociolinguistics, etc) this is not the class for you. I definitely learned a lot of cool stuff and I changed the way I think about language, but it didn't particularly make me want to take many more classes in the field.
I would recommend this course if you are really interested in linguistics - you will get a great introduction to the field. However, be prepared for somewhat arbitrary grading and delayed feedback.
Take this course if you like languages/language in general and want to learn more about how it works. Pretty technical but with some interesting applications to everyday life

I definitely recommend this course--it's fascinating and it gave me an entirely new perspective on language and an appreciation for the languages I speak. This course helped me understand linguistic phenomena I'd noticed vaguely throughout my life. Learning about linguistic rules was particularly interesting--I learned a lot about how we follow rules in language without ever explicitly learning them. The course's connections to themes of linguistic discrimination were especially interesting and made the course particularly relevant to the real world.

I would recommend this course to anyone interested in how language works. However, the first two weeks of the course are a bit misleading - the first two weeks cover the assumptions made in the field of linguistics and a little bit about socio linguistics, while the remainder of the course is more based in logical thinking and problem-solving. I dont have the greatest QR-brain, so I struggled a little bit learning how to work through phonology problems and syntax rules. My difficulties werent big enough to warrant going to office hours though (even though I did have to ask a Linguistics major friend for some help occasionally), and I did well in the class overall.
I would recommend this class to another student interested in gaining a basic knowledge of the field of linguistics. Its a fun class, but requires a fair amount of work and dedication.

Yes, definitely. I came into the class only intending to fulfil my SO requirement and left with so much more. The work is not too time-consuming and the material is absolutely fascinating. Jim has obviously perfected this class over the years and his delivery is wonderful -- take it even if this will be the only linguistics class you will ever take at Yale.

If you are really interested in learning about linguistics, then you'll like this class. It's worth noting that there's a lot of detailed memorization work about phonology and phonetics, so if you're an upperclassman looking for an easy but interesting intro class, this probably isn't your best bet because it does get kind of dense and complicated. But overall, if you are into the material, it's worth taking! You do learn a lot, and having shopped a few classes in the linguistics department, Jim Wood is definitely a better instructor than most.
This is a great course -- not too too hard, but also very informative and applicable to everyday life.
Great class, not a ton of work (neither quizzes nor psets were bad). As a CS major, this was my favorite class of the semester, and one of my favorite of all time.

I would recommend this class to people who are interested in the workings behind language and the system people follow when speaking a language. To those who enjoy learning new languages, this focuses more on the mechanics of language. Ths is a class that requires you to really study and understand the concepts on your time out of class.
I would not recommend this course because of the lack of organization.

The workload is pretty light, so there isn't much to worry about there. And since it's an introductroy class, you get to learn the basics of linguistics without going too deep into it. Take if you have a little interest in the field. If you already know some linguistics already then you might want to skip this; not because you won't learn anything but because there's not much application in class.

I would absolutely recommend Intro Linguistics. It's such a fun class, and the professor and all teaching staff are amazing. It's very approachable and if you don't like one section (for me this was syntax, for my friend phonetics) you will probably really like a different one (for me phonetics, my friend syntax). It's really fun to notice phenomena in everyday life and IPA is a seriously useful tool. I'm definitely going to take more linguistics classes! Also it's true, it's great for people with CS minds.

I would strongly recommend taking this course, especially if you have an interest in linguistics or one of its closely-related fields (psychology, computer science, etc.).  It covers four different areas within the field of linguistics linguistics (phonetics, phonology, morphology, and syntax); although you might not find all of these topics to be equally interesting, the course moves at a brisk enough pace that you will never stay on any one topic for too long.
I recommend this course to anyone interested in how language works even in the slightest. The lectures are entertaining and always a treat.
No

Yes, take this course! It's a good way to get a feel for the field of linguistics. It's challenging enough to be interesting, but it didn't feel devilishly hard and it didn't take over my life. It was fun :)

I would recommend this class but be prepared to spend extra time if this material does not come to you easily. I also recommend going to lecture because Prof. Wood tries to make sure that you understand the information after going to class. This is helpful so you don't have to cram and try to learn everything by yourself.

Would recommend for anyone who is fascinated by language - very interesting and exciting - taught in a very engaging way by a great, passionate teachers. I took this course just to dip my toe in to linguistics and am very satisfied. But I have seen it become busywork for those who weren't all that interested in the material.
